substitution.copyText: where be his quiddities now his quilietes, his case his tenures, and his tricks?
substitution.amendedText: where be his quiddities now ?his quilietes? his case? his tenures, and his tricks?

substitution.copyText: this fellow might bt in’s time a great buyer of land, with his statues, his recognisances, his fines, his double vouchers vouch him no more of his purchases and doubles, than the length and bredth of a pair of Indentures? the very conveyances of his land will scarcely lie in this box, and must th inheritor himself have no more? Ha?
Mine Sir, or a pit of clay for to be made. | I think it’s thine indeed, for thou lyft int. | You ly out on’t Sir,
substitution.amendedText: Mine Sir, -or a pit of clay for to be made.-- | I think it’s thine indeed; for thou ly’ft in’t. | You ly’e out on’t’ Sir,

substitution.copyText: Thou doest lye in’t, to be in’t and say it is thine,
substitution.amendedText: Thou doest lye in’t; to be in’t and say, it is thine

substitution.copyText: Horatio this three years I have took notice, of it, the age is grown so picked, that the toe of the pesant comes so near the hell of the Courtier, he galls his kibe
substitution.amendedText: Horatio these three years I have took notice, that the toe of the pesant comes so near the hell of the Courtier, he galls his kibe
